repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Programmatic Structural
            Adjustment Credit for Decentralization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Outcome
            is unsatisfactory; sustainability is unlikely; institutional
            development impact is negligible; Bank performance is
            unsatisfactory; and Borrower performance is unsatisfactory.
            The timing of the evaluation, with a mission conducted in
            February 2004, was particularly favorable for drawing
            lessons from this project's (PSAC I) implementation.
            First, because the follow-up operation, PSAC II, has also
            been completed, the two operations may be compared. Second,
            various reforms proposed by PSAC I required a longer term to
            materialize, which may not have been recognized as clearly
            if the evaluation had been carried out within the time frame
            established by the OED (six months). While analyzing the
            lessons learned, however, it must be remembered that the
            PSAC I was a first operation in a medium-term framework, and
            it was not intended to solve all the underlying problems of
            Bolivia's decentralization process. The lessons from
            the PSAC I may be grouped in four areas: (1) objective,
            content and approach of the operation; (2) design and
            management of the operation; (3) impact; and (4)
            sustainability. They include: setting overly ambitious
            objectives; limiting project scope too narrowly and
            neglecting to include the intermediate government level;
            needing to remove impediments to decentralization by
            reforming civil service and clarifying responsibilities
            among agencies delivering services recognizing that two
            tranches in adjustment operations should be maintained;
            realizing basket funding is not a substitute for effective
            coordination of ongoing activities; maintaining a balance
            between investment resources and unconditioned resources,
            and clarifying the use of each; continuing the participation
            of the same counterpart institutions; need to acquire data
            to assess impacts more clearly, particularly need to set a
            baseline at the beginning of the operation; recognizing that
            significant secondary impacts are not covered by the
            operation; recognizing that there exists no acceptable
            methodology for evaluating the impact of decentralization;
            and ensuring sustainability by studying the framework of
            incentives for participants in the decentralization process.

5085123.trustfund:
TF025603-PHRD-SECOND MUNICIPAL DEV. PROJECT,TF028328-BOLIVIA PROGRAMMATIC STRUCTURAL
            ADJUSTMENT CREDIT FOR DECENTARLIZATION

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Programmatic Structural
            Adjustment Credit for Decentralization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Programmatic Structural Adjustment
            Credit for Decentralization Project, will support
            Bolivia's reform program. The comprehensive
            decentralization reform program, already underway, aims to
            adapt the existing institutional framework for improved
            decentralized public service delivery, and governance to
            implement the Government's poverty reduction strategy.
            Specifically, the program will support the Government's
            efforts in improving the delivery of public services to the
            poor, through increased efficiency, transparency, and
            accountability of Bolivia's decentralized government
            system, and through improved capacity within the
            decentralized government system for delivery of these
            services. The reform program will improve regulatory, and
            institutional framework for decentralization; enhance
            community participation, particularly the poor, indigenous
            populations, and women; restore fiscal discipline;
            strengthen the government's financial, and
            institutional capacity to support delivery of public
            services; and, improve availability of credit financing for
            municipal investments. However, associated risks include the
            inherent lack of institutional capacity in a reform process
            already underway; socioeconomic deterioration due to
            political instability; and, potential lack of commitment to
            reform of the upcoming new administration in 2002.

docna.cdata!:
Bolivia - Programmatic Structural Adjustment
            Credit for Decentralization Project

Bolivia - Programmatic Structural
